Although rain dampened the
spirits of many on Saturday, the
various chairs of Spring Fair

weekend's event.
"I still have Spring Fair on my
mind," said Jill Kress, co-chair
of the Special Events Committee
for Maritime '89. "It's scary—
you plan for three months, but it
all really comes down to three
days. The planning is hard, but
once it starts, the Fair pretty
much runs itself."

Spring Fair Co-chair Beth
Friedman agreed, saying, "Once
it opens, Fair never closes." She
added that although the rain kept
most people away on Saturday,
the overwhelming crowds on Friday and Sunday helped Spring
Fair break even.
"The only money Fair might
have lost was beer money from
not selling kegs to frats," said

Officials urge greater awareness for security
by Alex Pham
and Anne Langley

Alexia Lennon

Foot escorts are available to walk with students around campus during
the nighttime.

Is there a crime crisis evolving
around Homewood?
As a result of this semester's
series of events, including two
assaults, one rape, and a
homicide, many students have
become more vocal about their
personal safety.
Perryne Constance, a graduate
student who lives on 26th and
North Calvert Streets, reported
feeling more uneasy about her environment when walking to and
from her home, particularly after
the murder of history graduate
student Bridgette Phillips. "Now
I pay more attention to the fact
that there could be someone else
out there," said Constance.
According to Major Robert
Larkin, director of Hopkins
Security, the recent wave of
crimes that have alarmed many
students do not indicate a trend.
"There have been a number of
unusual incidents," he said.

"This does not mean we have a
crisis on our hands."
Mark Tempesta, manager of
the Book and Card Fair store at
3121 St. Paul St., concurred.
"Even with the problems that are
going on, I've generally found the
area to be very safe," said
Tempesta, "but there is a difference between the student's
point of view and my own in that
I'm not the same kind of target.
University students have always
been prime targets anywhere you
go."
Not all students, however, are
especially surprised by the recent
number of crimes that have occurred in this area. "My sense of
security has not changed," said
Silke Weineck, a graduate student
who lives on the 2600 block of
North Calvert Street. "This is
because I've always been aware
that I'm in Baltimore, even when
I'm on campus. I can't understand why students think they're
in some kind of country-club setting and not in part of the city."

Unfortunately, this approach to
living in an urban setting like we
have here is not shared by all, or
even a majority, of students.
Awareness and attitude are two
important factors in preventing
crime. According to Sergeant
Tom Bull, neighborhood relations
director of the Baltimore Police
for the Norther District, which
encompasses Hopkins, "Students
are not crime conscious." Bull
explained that most crime could
be prevented with common sense,
and he stressed that persons,
students included, must take the
first steps in protecting
themselves.
Andrea Perry, director of
residential life, expressed a
similar concern. "Students and
staff feel they're invulnerable."
This feeling of invulnerability,
she said, is dangerous because it
lulls victims into a false sense of
safety, and thereby decreases
their awareness.

The special security problems
of a college campus were among
the issues addressed Tuesday,
April 11, at a Crime Awareness
seminar sponsored by the Phi Mu
sorority. The seminar was given
free by Citizens Against Crime,
a private national safety organization that has forty offices across
the country.
Julie Beckman, regional director of Citizens Against Crime and
the seminar leader, began by asking, "Do I have to convince you
that crime is a problem?" She
went on to say that always
remembering that crime is a problem is the first step in preventing it from occurring.
"Everybody has the potential to
be a victim," she said. "Once
you believe that, you heighten
your awareness and immediately
decrease the chances that it will
be you."
During the short, informative
seminar, Beckman pointed out
many common sense tips that
apply directly to students and can
be employed to avoid becoming
a victim. But first, she suggested
a look at the criminal's perspective: "Criminals do not strike at
random. They are looking for
victims who are quick, easy, and
no risk." To reduce the chances
of being a victim, she said,"You
need to give a criminal a reason
to pass you by."

difficult targets and, therefore,
less likely victims. However,
many students do not take the
time to attend a safety seminar
during their time at Hopkins,
even though some come to
Baltimore totally unprepared for
Hopkins's urban setting.
Many persons assume that
students receive all the information and training they need during the Orientation program, but
that is not always so. As Perry explained, students receive security manuals when they arrive, and
that her office tries to stress
repeatedly some instructions on
the major points of safety around
the dorms, which include locking
both individual and outside doors.
Security meetings are supposed to be held within each dorm.
Yet Larkin reported that this year
Hopkins Security met with only
a few groups of freshmen, and
added that most security information sessions held here are poorly attended. "We can't get to the
freshmen," he said.
Larkin emphasized the importance of informing freshmen early, before their living habits are
formed, so that common sense
and basic security measures can
become part of their natural indoctrination to Hopkins. Larkin
also expressed regret that, under
current programs, many students
are not contacted at all, particularly first-year grad students,

commuter students, and transfer
students. These are students who
do not participate in Orientation
but may come to Baltimore unprepared for the urban setting.
Susan Boswell, dean of
students, offers a balanced
perspective on the dual responsibilities of the student and the administration with regard to taking
measures to ensure an adequate
level of security.
"I think that students need to
take some responsibility for
themselves and each other, and to
do what they can to enhance their
own personal security," she said.
"The main role of the administration, on the other hand, is to raise
people's consciousness about the
realities of living in a city.
"That is not to say, however,
that campus security has no
responsibility," said Boswell. "I
think there's a real and genuine
concern on the part of administration about the safety of students."
Boswell noted various efforts
that the administration has taken
to enhance the safety of students,
including the regular sponsorship
of self-defense workshops and,
more recently, a series of three
seminars on personal safety held
in conjunction with the Baltimore
Police Department.
In addition, Hopkins Campus
Security provides a variety of services of which many students are
either unaware or do not take full
advantage. These include:
*Foot escorts in the immediate

area around campus from 5 p.m.
to 6 a.m.
*Free use of an engraving tool,
which students can use to etch
their social security number on
valubles such as stereos and
televisions so that the items can
be traced by the Federal Bureau
of Investigation should they get
stolen.
*The availability of Krypton
bike locks, which Security considers the most secure, at cost for
$16 (they usually sell for over
$35);
*Escort van service, which
operates within a mile radius of
the Hopkins campus daily between 5 p.m. and 2 a.m., and
*Twenty-four hour on-call service, at x7777, in case of an
emergency.
Campus security will also
patrol an office or lab when
students or staff are working late
into the evening, both for safety
and because the potential for accidents occurring in a lab can be
high. In extreme circumstances
when the student has no recourse,
campus patrol can pick up a
stranded student from as far away
as Towson State University or
Goucher College.
"We're not here just to write
tickets," said Dara D'Adio, a
campus security officer. "I want
students here to realize that they
are my boss, and that I work for
them. I want them to call on me
whenever they need me for
whatever reason."

Dean of Students Susan Boswell said students should take more responsibility for their own security.
The Hopkins Security employs
twenty-seven full-time security
officers, many of whom, like
D'Adio, are graduates of police
academies and have worked as
regular city police. Although they
are not allowed to carry guns,
campus security officers do have
powers of arrest, and search and
seizure.
Larkin noted that while the rate
of Baltimore crime has gone up,
the rate of crimes committed on
campus has, as a whole, declined.
Tempesta attributes the relative
security of the area surrounding
Homewood to the high visibility
of the Baltimore street police.
"The police here take an active
pursuit in the safety of
residents," said Tempesta."We
get visits from police even when
they're not on duty."

Orin Hughes, a Hopkins
security officer, believes the
quality of security around the area
can be strengthened by two
elements: students input and suggestions; and campus security's
close working relationship with
the Baltimore Police Department.
"It is remarkable that our student body cooperates so well and
so consistently with the security
office in terms of feedback and
suggestions," said Hughes.
"Many of the ideas of students
were implemented. For example,
the escort van was made available
at the suggestion of several
students.
"We also work hand and glove
with the Baltimore Police," continued Hughes. "I think it's best
when all parties concerned work
together."

Rupert speaks about football
The following interview with
Gary Rupert and the one with
Jedan Phillips on the next page
are the second in Greg Bronshvag's series highlighting senior
athletes.

Gary Rupert will graduate in
May with a B.A. in Social and
Behavioral Sciences after having
lettered four times in football, and
once in basketball. He was the
quarterback for the 1988 Hopkins
football team, and despite battling injuries his entire senior
season, came back to lead the
Jays over Western Maryland in
the season finale.
"Football has had its ups and
downs. The only major change
has been in our record. There are
more changes going on in the
other teams we play. Some teams
have made major changes in their
program while Hopkins has made
some minor changes.
"Next year, the team could
either do really well or the same
as this past season. Because a lot

of guys will be graduating, there
will be a lot of inexperience at
many key positions. It's going to
be up to the team to pick up the
slack. If they do that, they'll have
a good season.
"A definite plus is the fact that
Coach Pfeifer recruits a lot of
great athletes. For instance, my
sophomore year we had ten
quarterbacks in camp. Now, two
play linebacker, one plays defensive back, and another plays wide
receiver. We have linebackers
who switched to offensive
linemen. It helps to have so many
great athletes.
"The defense is always good,
and that's because Coach Babb
always does a good job. And
when it comes to designing plays,
Coach Pfeifer is very smart. Like
I said before, it's up to the players
themselves next year."
After playing football for four
years, Rupert has both good and
bad memories. "The Dickinson
game two years ago was great.
We were losing going into the
fourth quarter, and yet we won.
After that, we walked into the
Bull Roast, and nobody would
believe that we had won because
they all left the game early to go
eat.
"One thing I'd like to forget is
getting hurt. I've been injured
every year I've played. No matter who the team is, everyone is
out to get the quarterback. So I'd
get cheap shots taken at me all the
time, usually after I'd released the
ball. After that, moving around
the house the next day was painful. Sometimes, I wouldn't be

able to practice until the following Wednesday.
"I chose Hopkins for its
academics and name. People are
always impressed with Hopkins
graduates. I've enjoyed it, and
because of it, I've done a lot of
other things and made many
friends for life.
"But people [at Hopkins] need
to relax a little more and just have
fun. There's nothing wrong with
coming to watch the football team
on a Saturday afternoon,
regardless of whether or not the
team wins. I know people here
who'll sit and watch the
hometown pro-football team lose
50-0 on TV on Sunday, and yet
they won't come up on a Saturday to watch our game.
"Good crowds would definitely help at football games. You get
more pumped up playing before
a noisy crowd. Nobody went to
the basketball games until the end
of the season when they were
winning, except for someone like
Mr. Scott. He's done a really
good job. He shows up at every
game for all sports here. He
knows all the athletes by name
and congratulates them after
every game. He always show his
support. It would be nice if people could show support for all
teams like he does."
Gary plans to stay on the field,
but only from the sidelines.
"I plan to take classes towards
a teaching certificate, so I can
teach at a public school and also
coach there. That could be the
stepping stone to a collegiatelevel job.

The course is still in the planning stage, but some elements are set. The
class will read together this brief, but very significant, part of the Bible. As

understanding Genesis, and in a broader sense, the whole of the Jewish and

gathering information, outlining, writing, and revision. The course might have

Westbrook

Greece and Rome from the earliest known records until the Fifth century
B.C. Main topics: sources of law, property and family law, contract and debt,
crime and tort, constitutional and international law. Required reading consists
mainly of original sources in translation. Taught by a lawyer, the course will
compare the legal concepts of the world's oldest know systems with those of
modern law.
130.452-453 Modern Hebrew Literature M3, W9, 3 credits, Instructor: Dr.
lwry

train the students in the art of close reading and analyzing of Modern
Hebrew texts, accessible short stories, excerpts from popular novellas, or
*ridged pieces from current periodicals. The main target of the course will
be the perusal of a limited selection of writings by S.J. Angon, the Nobel
Prize Laureate of Hebrew Literature. This will include some of his
autobiographical stories, his traditional epic narratives, and a couple of his
wonder tales of a surrealistic nature. Similarly, for the sake of comparative
orientation, one or two items 1-Nrm contemporary Israeli writers, such as A.B.
Yehoshua and Amos Oz, will be included.
All through the course, which will be conducted in Hebrew, emphasis will be
given to the phenomena of style and grammatical construction, thematic con-

text, and the characteristic milieu of the works selected. To improve the
quality of speaking and writing skills, a few summaries or short compositions
plus a limited amount of weekly reading will be requested.
130.470 Arabic I MTW 10, 3 credits, Instructor: Dr. Krotkoff
This is probably the last time that Arabic will be offered at JHU in Baltimore.
This introductory language course is taught during both semesters of the
academic year, and according to University regulations credit is given only to
those who enroll for both terms. Arabic is not a homogenous language, and
we distinguish between Classical, Modern Literary, and numerous local vernaculars. The latter are used in everyday conversation, but only the literary
(aka MSA 5 Modern Standard Arabic) is the same for the entire Arab world
and considered fit for writing. It is, therefore advisable to start with MSA.
Learning Arabic , barring some ulterior motivations, should be taken as an
intellectual exercise and adventure. Learners must accept that there is more
than one *ay of expressing thought and agree to acquire a set of rules different from that of their own language, including a completely new script.
Those who know their own language well and who have given language
some thought before will be at an advantage. The instruction will concentrate
on reading, grammatical analysis, translation, structure, semantics, and
cultural differences. A professor-published study aid and a dictionary must
be acquired. Interest and continuous preparedness in class are the most important conditions for success. . , ,

Rupert speaks about football
The following interview with
Gary Rupert and the one with
Jedan Phillips on the next page
are the second in Greg Bronshvag's series highlighting senior
athletes.

Gary Rupert will graduate in
May with a B.A. in Social and
Behavioral Sciences after having
lettered four times in football, and
once in basketball. He was the
quarterback for the 1988 Hopkins
football team, and despite battling injuries his entire senior
season, came back to lead the
Jays over Western Maryland in
the season finale.
"Football has had its ups and
downs. The only major change
has been in our record. There are
more changes going on in the
other teams we play. Some teams
have made major changes in their
program while Hopkins has made
some minor changes.
"Next year, the team could
either do really well or the same
as this past season. Because a lot

of guys will be graduating, there
will be a lot of inexperience at
many key positions. It's going to
be up to the team to pick up the
slack. If they do that, they'll have
a good season.
"A definite plus is the fact that
Coach Pfeifer recruits a lot of
great athletes. For instance, my
sophomore year we had ten
quarterbacks in camp. Now, two
play linebacker, one plays defensive back, and another plays wide
receiver. We have linebackers
who switched to offensive
linemen. It helps to have so many
great athletes.
"The defense is always good,
and that's because Coach Babb
always does a good job. And
when it comes to designing plays,
Coach Pfeifer is very smart. Like
I said before, it's up to the players
themselves next year."
After playing football for four
years, Rupert has both good and
bad memories. "The Dickinson
game two years ago was great.
We were losing going into the
fourth quarter, and yet we won.
After that, we walked into the
Bull Roast, and nobody would
believe that we had won because
they all left the game early to go
eat.
"One thing I'd like to forget is
getting hurt. I've been injured
every year I've played. No matter who the team is, everyone is
out to get the quarterback. So I'd
get cheap shots taken at me all the
time, usually after I'd released the
ball. After that, moving around
the house the next day was painful. Sometimes, I wouldn't be

able to practice until the following Wednesday.
"I chose Hopkins for its
academics and name. People are
always impressed with Hopkins
graduates. I've enjoyed it, and
because of it, I've done a lot of
other things and made many
friends for life.
"But people [at Hopkins] need
to relax a little more and just have
fun. There's nothing wrong with
coming to watch the football team
on a Saturday afternoon,
regardless of whether or not the
team wins. I know people here
who'll sit and watch the
hometown pro-football team lose
50-0 on TV on Sunday, and yet
they won't come up on a Saturday to watch our game.
"Good crowds would definitely help at football games. You get
more pumped up playing before
a noisy crowd. Nobody went to
the basketball games until the end
of the season when they were
winning, except for someone like
Mr. Scott. He's done a really
good job. He shows up at every
game for all sports here. He
knows all the athletes by name
and congratulates them after
every game. He always show his
support. It would be nice if people could show support for all
teams like he does."
Gary plans to stay on the field,
but only from the sidelines.
"I plan to take classes towards
a teaching certificate, so I can
teach at a public school and also
coach there. That could be the
stepping stone to a collegiatelevel job.
